what: Introduction to the use of Global Statistical Approach
title: GST Tutorial
text: Determination whether one treatment preferred others major goal many clinical studies can complicated situation single outcome sufficient make judgement. package introduces useful global statistics test technique corresponding global treatment effect (GTE) measure, employs nonparametric method based composite rank-sum diverse variables assessing treatment’s global preference multiple outcomes evaluated together. Measure treatment benefit outcome defined \(\theta = p - q\) difference probability treatment better control probability control better treatment. multiple outcomes, compute \(\theta\) outcome take average \(\bar{\theta}\) values.\(\bar{\theta}\) value called global treatment effect (GTE) Interpretation GTE straightforward: GTE = 0. indicates global difference treatment 1 2, GTE > 0 indicates treatment 2 gives globally higher values treatment 1 GTE < 0 indicates treamtent 2 gives globally smaller values treatment 1. GTE values approaching 1 implies increased treatment 2’s global values treatment 1, whereas GTE values approaching -1 suggest decreased treatment 2’s global values treatment 1. O’Brien’s rank-sum type GST simple useful method compare treatment’s global effect multiple outcomes. appropriate \(\bar{\theta}_a\) value target magnitude treatment effect determined, one ready set hypotheses, compute sample size needed, test treatment global effect using O’Brien’s GST data collected. Determination global treatment effect, computation sample size testing GTE using functions included package illustrated Part , II III respectively.

what: Part I. Determination of the global treatment effect
title: GST Tutorial
text: section describes compute global treatment effect \(\bar{\theta}\) pilot data (available) summary statistics (pilot data available). pilot data: pilot data, can directly use theta function package. Data consistently coded ensure larger values indicate better outcomes measures. Example: x1 100 random samples t-distribution 50 degrees freedom, x2 100 random samples t-distribution 2 degrees freedom. treat x1 outcomes group 1 x2 outcomes group 2 pilot data. \(\bar{\theta}\) calculated follow: scenario, global treatment effect \(\bar{\theta}\) = 0.3056, indicating group 2 gives globally higher values group 1. pilot data, summary statistics: pilot data, investigators can estimate treatment effect based information literature. cases, information presented terms mean standard deviation using normal approximation, presented using summary statistics parametric distributions. studies, nonlinear monotone transformations (eg., log transformation, square root transformations, etc.) applied data obtain better parametric approximation, summary statistics transformed data reported. Fortunately, problem GTE used measure treatment’s effect since GTE unchanged computed observation ranks. brief illustration GTE’s invariance property nonlinear monotone transformation: table shows, GTE change applying nonlinear monotone transformation effect size varies significantly. Example: Suppose hypothetical summary statistics using normal approximation shown . outcome 1, group 2(treatment) gives globally smaller values group 1 (control). outcome 2, global difference group 1 2. outcome 3, group 2 gives globally higher values group 1.
code: set.seed(123) x1<- rt(100, 50, ncp = 10) x2<- rt(100, 2, ncp = 10.3) # use original data: theta_1 <- theta(x1,x2)  theta_1 #> [1] 0.3056 # effect size when comparing x1 and x2: effect_size1 <- abs(mean(x1)-mean(x2))/sqrt(var(c(x1,x2))) # take log-transformation of the data: y1<- log(x1) y2<- log(x2) # theta: theta_2 <- theta(y1,y2) # effect size when comparing y1 and y2: effect_size2 <- abs(mean(y1)-mean(y2))/sqrt(var(c(y1,y2)))  # take square transformation of the data: z1<- x1^3 z2<- x2^3 # theta: theta_3 <- theta(z1,z2)  # effect size when comparing z1 and z2: effect_size3 <- abs(mean(z1)-mean(z2))/sqrt(var(c(z1,z2)))  compare <- as.data.frame(matrix(c(theta_1, theta_2, theta_3,                                  effect_size1, effect_size2, effect_size3),                                 nrow = 3, ncol = 2)) colnames(compare) <- c("GTE", "Effect size") rownames(compare) <- c("Normal", "Log-transformed", "square_transformed") compare #>                       GTE Effect size #> Normal             0.3056   0.4794255 #> Log-transformed    0.3056   0.5697520 #> square_transformed 0.3056   0.1708347 mu1 = c(30, 40, 50) stdev1 = c(3, 4, 5) mu2 = c(10, 40, 70) stdev2 = c(5, 6, 7)  summary_data <- data.frame(   Outcome_Scale = c("Outcome 1", "Outcome 2", "Outcome 3"),   Placebo_Mean = mu1,   Placebo_SD = stdev1,   Treatment_Mean = mu2,   Treatment_SD = stdev2 )  kable(summary_data,        col.names = c("Outcome scale", "Placebo Mean", "Placebo SD", "Treatment Mean", "Treatment SD"),        align = 'c') theta <- 2*pnorm((mu2-mu1)/sqrt(stdev1^2+stdev2^2))-1 theta #> [1] -0.9993964  0.0000000  0.9799255

what: Part II. Determination of sample size
title: GST Tutorial
text: Sample size estimation historical data available use N.GSTwPilotData function derive sample size pilot data. Functions required inputs : 1. data: (m1+m2) x k matrix pilot data first m1 rows treatment 1, rest m2 rows treatment 2. k number endpoints 2. m1: number patients treatment 1 pilot data 3. r0: randomization ratio new study = n2/n1 4. test.side: 1(one-sided test) 2 (two-sided test) 5. alpha: type error controlled 6. power: statistical power controlled 7. GTE: global treatment effect power controlled . 3 endpoints hypothetical historical dataset. first 40 rows random observations treatment 1 follow standard normal distribution. rest 60 rows random observations treatment 2 follow normal distribution mean 0.6. Now, suppose goal attain 0.05 significance level 90% power two sided hypothesis testing. pass requirements function: result shows, need 66 participants group 1 nd 100 participants group 2. Sample size estimation historical data available use N.GSTnoData function derive sample size pilot data. Functions required inputs : 1. k: number endpoints 2. r0: randomization ratio = n2/n1 3. GTE: target GTE power controlled 4. sigma2: upper bound variances F1(X2) F2(X1) 5. rho: Spearman rank correlation 6. alpha: type error 7. power: desired statistical power 8. test.side: 1(one-sided test) 2 (two-sided test) Using hypothetical summary statistics using normal approximation : can calculate GTE sigma2, plug function get sample size estimation.
code: # hypothetical pilot data set.seed(123) k<- 3 n1<- 40 N<- 100 n2<- N-n1 x1<- rnorm(N) data<- cbind(x1/sqrt(2)+rnorm(N)/sqrt(2),               x1/sqrt(2)+rnorm(N)/sqrt(2),               x1/sqrt(2)+rnorm(N)/sqrt(2)) x2<- rnorm(n2, mean=0.6) data2<- cbind(x2/sqrt(2)+rnorm(n2)/sqrt(2),               x2/sqrt(2)+rnorm(n2)/sqrt(2),               x2/sqrt(2)+rnorm(n2)/sqrt(2)) data[(n1+1):N,]<- data[(n1+1):N,]+data2 head(data)  #>             [,1]       [,2]       [,3] #> [1,] -0.89864943  1.1584776 -0.9020687 #> [2,]  0.01888415  0.7652561 -0.6949915 #> [3,]  0.92773572  0.9146874  0.4385261 #> [4,] -0.19589277  0.4339532 -0.6943823 #> [5,] -0.58147571 -0.2015624 -0.2176982 #> [6,]  1.18089467  0.8759767  1.4469131 # calculate sample size N.GSTwPilotData(data, m1=n1,    r0=n2/n1, test.side=2, alpha=0.05, power=0.9, GTE=NA) #> [1] "sample size in treatment 1 = 66" #> [1] "sample size in treatment 2 = 100" #> [1] "unbiased estimate of GTE = 0.231388888888889" #> $n1 #> [1] 66 #>  #> $n2 #> [1] 100 #>  #> $theta.pilot #> [1] 0.2541667 0.3083333 0.1316667 kable(summary_data,        col.names = c("Outcome scale", "Placebo Mean", "Placebo SD", "Treatment Mean", "Treatment SD"),        align = 'c') GTE<- mean(theta) sigma2<- min((1-min(theta^2))/4, 1/12)  # rest of the variables are pre-determined: k<- length(mu1) # number of endpoints alpha<- 0.05 # type I error beta<- 0.1 # 90% power test.side<- 2 r0<- 1 # randomization ratio rho<- 0.1 N.GSTnoData(k, r0, GTE, sigma2, rho, alpha, beta, test.side) #> [1] "sample size in treatment 1 = 2914" #> [1] "sample size in treatment 2 = 2913" #> $n1 #> [1] 2914 #>  #> $n2 #> [1] 2913 #>  #> $N #> [1] 5827

what: Part III. Use of global statistical testing in data analysis
title: GST Tutorial
text: previous sections, ’ve determined appropriate \(\bar{\theta_a}\) target magnitude treatment effect, set hypotheses, computed sample size needed, now, can test treatment’s global effect determining test statistics using GST.parameter function. p-value GST obtained comparing value Z critical values normal distribution. example dataset hypothetical historical data previous section 3 endpoints, first 40 rows contain observations group 1 rest 60 rows contain observations group 2. can use GST.parameter function calculate useful parameters like treatment effect individual outcomes, standard deviation global treatment effect etc. p-value GST obtained comparing value Z critical values normal distribution. example, Z = 1.645 corresponds p = 0.05 one-sided test p = 0.10 two-sided test; Z = 1.960 corresponds p = 0.025 one-sided test p = 0.05 two-sided test. Alternatively, GST function directly provide one/two-sided non-parametric global statistical test p-values. GST.simu
code: head(data) #>             [,1]       [,2]       [,3] #> [1,] -0.89864943  1.1584776 -0.9020687 #> [2,]  0.01888415  0.7652561 -0.6949915 #> [3,]  0.92773572  0.9146874  0.4385261 #> [4,] -0.19589277  0.4339532 -0.6943823 #> [5,] -0.58147571 -0.2015624 -0.2176982 #> [6,]  1.18089467  0.8759767  1.4469131 # get p-value from GST: x <- GST.parameter(data, n1) Z <- sum(x$theta) * sqrt(N) / 2 / sum(x$Sigma) Z #> [1] 1.827365 1-pnorm(Z) # mismatch? #> [1] 0.03382247 GST(data=data, m=n1, test.side = 1) #> $p.value #> [1] 0.004514176 #>  #> $h #> [1] 0.9225368 #>  #> $theta.hat #> [1] 0.2541667 0.3083333 0.1316667 #>  #> $GTE #> [1] 0.2313889 #>  #> $sigmaGTE #> [1] 0.09187831 m<- 50 # sample size in treatment group 1 n<-  50 # sample size in treatment group 2 k<- 20 # number of endpoints r<- rep(1, k) rho<- 0.01 # correlation simu<- 5  i<-1 dataset<- array(rnorm((m+n)*k*simu,0,1) , dim=c(m+n,k, simu))  for (j in 2:k) #introduce correlation for group 1  {dataset[1:m,j,]<- sqrt(rho)*dataset[1:m,1,]+sqrt(1-rho)*dataset[1:m,j,]  } dataset[(m+1):(m+n),1,]<- matrix(rnorm(n*simu,0,r[1]), nrow=n,ncol=simu) for (j in 2:k) #introduce correlation for group 2 { dataset[(m+1):(m+n),j,]<- sqrt(rho)*dataset[(m+1):(m+n),1,]+sqrt(1-rho)*                        matrix(rnorm(n*simu,0,r[j]), nrow=n,ncol=simu) } delta<- 0.15 # introduce difference between group 1 and group 2 dataset[(m+1):(m+n),,]<- dataset[(m+1):(m+n),,]+delta dim(dataset) #[1] 100  20   5 #> [1] 100  20   5  # GST from simulated data: x<- GST.simu(data=dataset,m)
